## Different beta diversity analysis tools

<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/jinhuili-lab/personal_image_bed/master/img99202201112153833.png" style="zoom: 50%;" />



### Different drawing tools



### PCoA

**Dissimilarity index**, partial match to "manhattan", "euclidean", "canberra", "clark", "bray", "kulczynski", "jaccard", "gower", "altGower", "morisita", "horn", "mountford", "raup", "binomial", "chao", "cao", "mahalanobis", "chisq" or "chord".

**The Jaccard and Bray-curtis dissimilarity** coefficients are **commonly** used in bioinformatics analysis and are the basis for calculating species similarity.

It should be noted that the focus of these two dissimilarity coefficients is different.

In analysis, Jaccard only considers the presence or absence of species in the sample, not the abundance.

The Bray-curtis calculation not only considers the presence or absence of species in the sample, but also considers the relative abundance of different species.

<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/jinhuili-lab/personal_image_bed/master/img99202201112153834.png" style="zoom:33%;" /><img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/jinhuili-lab/personal_image_bed/master/img99202201112153835.png" style="zoom:33%;" />

This button can choose whether to perform **R-value and P-value** calculations on the data.
R^2 can quantify the strength of the relationship between the model response variable and the dependent variable.
The p-value test can determine how reliable the fitted equation is.

<img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/jinhuili-lab/personal_image_bed/master/img99202201112153836.png" style="zoom:33%;" /><img src="https://raw.githubusercontent.com/jinhuili-lab/personal_image_bed/master/img99202201112153837.png" style="zoom:33%;" />
